delim|delim
elsevier ltdepigenetic mechanisms comprise all those phenomena that influence chromatin structure and gene expression without modifying the sequence of the dna . dna methylation and hydroxymethylation are modifications that pertain a single base of the dna , . the cytosine ( ) . while dna methylation has been extensively studied and its effects on gene expression demonstrated in relation to several genes , dna hydroxymetilation has been recently described and the mechanisms of regulation have not been fully elucidated . histone modifications ( ) are the modification of the aminoacids in the histone tails that can be acetylated , methylated , adp-ribosylated , ubiquitinated , and phosphorylated . the modifications of specific residues of the histones , in particular through acetylation and methylation , determine conformational changes in the chromatin , a phenomenon known as chromatin remodeling ( ) . the small non coding rnas , and in particular micrornas ( mirnas ) , have been recently recognized as epigenetic mechanisms for its capacity to modulate the expression of specific genes . the mirnas are encoded by mirna genes and the transcripts are then modified in the cytosol to produce the mature mirnas that regulate specific target mrnas ( ) . fig . 1 . one-carbon metabolism provides the methyl groups for biological methylation reactions and for nucleotide synthesis . several nutrients actively influence the pathway : folate , involved in the delivery of methyl groups ; vitamin b6 , coenzyme of serine hydroxymethyltransferase ( shmt ) ; vitamin b2 , coenzyme of methylenetetrahydrofolate reductase ( mthfr ) ; vitamin b12 , coenzyme of methionine synthase ( ms ) ; several aminoacids such as methionine that is critical for the synthesis of s-adenosylmethionine ( sadomet ) , the universal methyl-donor for biological methylation reactions . fig . 2one-carbon metabolism nutrients known to influence epigenetic mechanisms . table 1epigenetic mechanismone-carbon gene . open box and line represent exon and intron , respectively . the arrow shows the position of nucleotide substitution at the acceptor site of intron 17 . dna sequence was based on the genbank data base ( accession number ) . ( d ) amino-acid sequence of bromodomain of p / caf and p300 protein . asterisks show the residues of the p / caf bromodomain that interact with acetyl-histamine . the underlined residues were predictively deleted in the mutant protein in cem . p / caf , p300 / cbp-associated factor . genbank accession number : p / caf , ; p300 , . a missense mutation at codon 507 ( s507g ) of p300 in an mds patient . ( a ) sscp analysis of the pcr product of fragment pb1 . lane 1 , pbmnc from a healthy volunteer ; lane 2 , bmmncs from mds patient . arrow shows the band that abnormally migrated . ( b ) dna sequence of the mutated allele . patients characteristicss|1 17 2 507 a a a abnormally acceptor accession accession acetyl acid allel amino an analysis arrow arrow associated asterisks at at b band base based bmmncs box bromodomain bromodomain caf caf caf caf cbp cem characteristicss codon d data deleted dna dna exon factor fragment from from genbank genbank gene healthy histamine interact intron intron lane lane line mds mds migrated missense mutant mutated mutation nucleotide number number open p p p p p300 p300 p300 p300 patient patient patients pb1 pbmnc pcr position predictively product protein protein represent residues residues respectively s507g sequence sequence sequence shew shows shows site sscp substitution that that underlined volunteer was were

elsevier ireland ltdepigenetic modifications of chromatin structure : different epigenetic modifications in chromatin during transcriptionally active and inactive state . dm ( demethylase ) , dnmt ( dna methyltransferase ) , hat ( histone acetyl transferase ) , hdac ( histone deacetylase ) , hmt ( histone methyltransferase ) . epigenetics and dcm : putative pathways and their candidate genes involved in pathophysiology of diabetic cardiomyopathy ( dcm ) . rectangular boxes show the genes which have shown to be epigenetically modulated in other diseases . et-1 , endothelin 1 ; f . a . , fatty acid ; ros , reactive oxygen species ; age , advanced glycation end products ; mhc , myosin heavy chain ; at1r , angiotenin1 receptor ; gult , glucose transporter ; serca , sarcoplasmic reticulum ca-atpase ; col4 , collagen type iv ; ppar , peroxisome proliferator activated receptor ; raas , renin – angiotensin aldosterone system ; hif , hypoxia inducing factor ; vegf , vascular endothelial growth factor and tgf , transforming growth factor . ⁎ . tel . : + 91 9316131057 ; fax : + 91 1722744401 . cardiovascular complications are a chief cause of mortality and morbidity in diabetic patients . recent studies suggest that epigenetic changes which may arise as a consequence of environmental factors play an important role in predisposition to disease . epigenetic mechanisms such as dna methylation , chromatin remodeling and histone modifications regulate the gene expression in response to environmental signals . role of epigenetics has been recognized in the pathology of diabetes , however its role in diabetic associated cardiomyopathy remains largely unexplored . in this article , we review current literature on the epigenetic mechanisms involved in diabetes and discuss recent evidence of epigenetic changes that may play an important role in pathophysiology of dcm . diabetes is the most common modifiable risk factor , and is a significant contributor to death|1 1 1722744401 91 91 9316131057 a a a a acetyl acid activated active advanced age aldosterone an an angiotenin1 angiotensin are arise article as as associated at1r atpase be been boxes ca candidate cardiomyopathy cardiomyopathy cardiovascular cause chain changes changes chief chromatin chromatin chromatin col4 collagen common complications consequence contributor current dcm dcm dcm deacetylase death demethylase diabetes diabetes diabetes diabetic diabetic diabetic different discuss disease diseases dm dna dna dnmt during elsevier end endothelial endothelin environmental environmental epigenetic epigenetic epigenetic epigenetic epigenetic epigenetically epigenetics epigenetics et evidence expression f factor factor factor factor factors fatty fax gene genes genes glucose glycation growth growth gult has hat have hdac heavy hif histone histone histone histone hmt however hypoxia important important inactive inducing involved involved ireland is is its iv largely literature ltdepigenetic may may mechanisms mechanisms methylation methyltransferase methyltransferase mhc modifiable modifications modifications modifications modulated morbidity mortality delim|delim
elsevier b . v . molecular mechanisms through which hypoxia regulates histone methylation and gene expression ( ) in normoxia , hif-α is hydroxylated by phd enzymes at its proline residues and is subsequently subjected to vhl-mediated ubiquitination and proteasomal degradation . additionally , asparagine hydroxylation by fih blocks hif-α recruitment of cbp / p300 coactivators . under hypoxia , hif-α is stabilized and translocated to the nucleus , where it dimerizes with hif-β to induce the expression of histone-modifying enzyme genes with hre sequences . ( ) phd1 destabilizes histone methyltransferase g9a through proline hydroxylation and the vhl-driven ubiquitin-proteasome pathway . fih hydroxylates g9a and glp at asparagine residues to inhibit their methyltransferase activities . in hypoxia , g9a and glp are activated and repress a subset of anti-metastatic genes by adding h3k9me2 / 3 marks . ( ) the histone demethylases kdm5a and kdm6a are activated to demethylate h3k4 and h3k27 , respectively , in an oxygen-dependent manner . under hypoxia , they are inactivated , and gene expression is readjusted to cope with hypoxia . fig . 1hif-induced oncogenic histone modifiers in the cancer . a group of hif-induced histone modifiers ( kdm3a , kdm4b , kdm4c , kdm7b , and ezh2 ) epigenetically activate oncogenes that promote cancer progression in a hypoxic microenvironment . conversely , kdm5b promotes cancer progression by repressing tumor suppressor genes . nsclc , non-small-cell lung carcinoma . fig . 2hypoxia-responsive histone methyltransferases and demethylases . table 1categorynamealiaseshistone targetsexpression in hypoxiaactivity in hypoxiag|1categorynamealiaseshistone 1hif 2hypoxia 3 a a a activate activated activated activities adding additionally alpha alpha alpha an anti are are are asparagine asparagine at at b beta blocks cancer cancer cancer carcinoma cbp cell coactivators conversely cope degradation demethylases demethylases demethylate dependant destabilizes dimerizes driven elsevier enzyme enzymes epigenetically expression expression expression ezh2 fig fig fih fih g9a g9a g9a gene gene genes genes genes glp glp group h3k27 h3k4 h3k9me2 hif hif hif hif hif histone histone histone histone histone histone histone hre hydroxylated hydroxylates hydroxylation hydroxylation hypoxia hypoxia hypoxia hypoxia hypoxia hypoxiaactivity hypoxiag hypoxic inactivated induce induced induced inhibit is is is is it its kdm3a kdm4b kdm4c kdm5a kdm5b kdm6a kdm7b lung manner marks mechanisms mediated metastatic methylation methyltransferase methyltransferase methyltransferases microenvironment modifiers modifiers modifying molecular non normoxia nsclc nucleus oncogenes oncogenic oxygen p300 pathway phd phd1 progression progression proline proline promote promotes proteasomal proteasome readjusted recruitment regulates repress repressing residues residues respectively responsive sequences small stabilized subjected subsequently subset suppresser table targetsexpression that their they thru thru translocated tumor ubiquitin ubiquitination under under v vhl vhl where which

delim|delim
elsevier ltdschematic depicts the epigenetics modifications in the development of organ fibrosis . micro-repetitive injuries caused by the external stimuli such as environmental stress , chemical drugs may alter gene expression through epigenetic mechanisms . epigenetic modifications include dna methylation , histone post translational modifications , chromatin remodeling complexes and non-coding rnas . several studies have demonstrated that these altered epigenetic modifications lead to aberrant expression of genes related to myofibroblast proliferation and differentiation — involved in the development and progression of organ fibrosis . fig . 1an overview of the atp-dependent chromatin remodeling complexes . ( a ) iswi and chd remodeling complexes are involved in the spacing of nucleosome . ( b ) swi / snf remodeling complexes are involved in the nucleosome ejection and sliding . ( c ) ino80 remodeling complexes are involved in the histone editing . iswi , imitation switch ; chd , chromodomain helicase dna ; swi / snf , switch / sucrose non-fermentable ; ino80 , inositol requiring mutant 80 . fig . 2epigenetic drugs that have entered clinical trials in the context of fibrotic diseases . table 1compoundmode of actioncompanyphasediseasenct iiacute kidney injurynct04342975valproic acidhdac inhibitoruniversity hospital brusselphase ii / phase iiiidiopathic nephrotic syndrome|1an 1compoundmode 2epigenetic 80 a aberrant acidhdac actionbeth delim|delim
the domain architecture of the evolutionary conserved methyl-binder subunit of major classes of cd proteins in human genome . each protein contains a distinctive cd structural fold that is shown with corresponding amino acid numbers . chd superfamily of proteins harbour two tandem cds represented as cd1 and cd2 . hp1 isoforms in human : cbx1 , cbx3 and cbx5 consists of a csd along with the consensus cd . csd is situated at the c-terminus of cd region in hp1 isoforms . pc homologs : cbx2 , cbx4 , cbx6 , cbx7 and cbx8 harbours a single cd located at their n-terminus . cd regions in four cdy isoforms , two kmts : suv39h1 and suv39h2 , kat8 , msl3 and dcaf1 are represented . other specific domains for various chromatin functions are not shown . illustrated domains are in scale with the size of the proteins . fig . 1structure-based sequence alignment and organization of the cds . amino acid numbers of first and last residue in the alignment are noted . tandem cd1-cd2 from chd proteins and csd from hp1 isoforms are aligned independently . aromatic cage residues that recognize methylated lysines are in purple and shown with asterisks below . well conserved aromatic residues outside cage regions forms a complementary surface facilitating methyl-recognition are highlighted in purple and colon . conserved positive and negative charged residues are indicated as blue and red . black dots indicated the family specific conserved residues . fig . 2unrooted phylogenetic tree of cds and chromo barrel domains . the sequence alignment was used to construct the phylogenetic map of cd containing proteins . fig . 3mutation map of chromodomain-containing proteins in major tumor types . each dot represents the mutation in a single protein with respect to the tumor type . the multiple mutations in each protein corresponding single cancer type are indicated by # mark along with numbers . missense mutations are shown in red . description of cancer type is indicated as : aml-acute myeloid leukemia , acc-adrenocortical carcinoma , buc-bladder urothelial carcinoma , bic-breast invasive carcinoma , bidc-breast invasive ductal car|1structure 2unrooted 3mutation a a a a a acc acid acid acute adrenocortical aligned alignment alignment alignment along along amino amino aml architecture are are are are are are are are are are aromatic aromatic as as as asterisks at at barrel based below bic bidc binder black bladder blue breast breast buc c cage cage cancer cancer car carcinoma carcinoma carcinoma cbx1 cbx2 cbx3 cbx4 cbx5 cbx6 cbx7 cbx8 cd cd cd cd cd cd cd cd1 cd1 cd2 cd2 cds cds cds cdy charged chd chd chromatin chromo chromodomain classes colon complementary consensus conserved conserved conserved conserved consists construct containing containing contains corresponding corresponding csd csd csd dcaf1 description distinctive domain domains domains domains dot dots ductal each each each evolutionary facilitating family fig fig fig first fold forms four from from functions genome harbor harbours highlighted homologs hp1 hp1 hp1 human human illustrated independently indicated indicated indicated indicated invasive invasive is is is isoforms isoforms isoforms isoforms kat8 kmts last leukemia located lysines major major map map mark methyl methyl methylated missense msl3 multiple mutation mutations mutations myeloid n negative not noted numbers delim|delim
clinically effective differentiation therapy in acute myelogenous leukemia ( aml ) has been demonstrated only in the m3 t ( 15 ; 17 ) acute promyelocytic leukemia ( apl ) . in apl , all-retinoic acid ( atra ) induces leukemic cell terminal differentiation and hematologic remission in 90 % of patients . this remarkable clinical observation was initially based on the observation that retinoids induced terminal cell division in established leukemia cell lines . this biological observation and treatment of apl was made prior to the knowledge that dominant negative repression of rarα nuclear receptor function by pml rarα , the product of t ( 15 ; 17 ) , was the molecular basis for leukemic transformation in apl . the understanding of the molecular basis of the myeloid transformation to apl resulting from the pml rarα protein has brought forward a model for the development of novel strategies for overcoming the site-specific transcriptional repression involved in the transformation ( ) . rarα in heterodimeric form with rxr is associated with an n-cor / sin3a / histone deacetylase ( hdac1 ) corepressor complex . rarα is maintained in a repressed state when associated with the corepressor as a result of deacetylation of histone tails within the nucleosome resulting in less accessibility to basal transcription factors . during normal myeloid differentiation ( ) , physiologic concentrations of atra induce confirmational changes in the rarα causing dissociation of the corepressor complex with subsequent recruitment of an src co-activator complex with intrinsic histone acetyltransferase activity . the subsequent acetylation of histone tails disrupts the tightly packed and repressed chromatin structure allowing for access to the basal transcription factors and transcriptional activation . site-specific transcriptional repression by pml rarα protein results from inefficient dissociation of the n-cor repressor complex from the fusion protein at physiologic concentrations of atra ( ) . pharmacologic amounts of atra ( 1μ ) are required to dissociate the n-cor corepressor complex and initiate a chromatin structure amenable to transcriptional activation . other forms of acute leukemias are associated with translations which encode fusion leukemo|15 15 17 17 1mu 90 a a a a access accessibility acetylation acetyltransferase acid activation activation activator activity acute acute acute all allowing amenable aml amounts an an apl apl apl apl apl are are as associated associated associated at atra atra atra atra basal basal based basis basis been biological brought causing cell cell cell changes chromatin chromatin clinical clinically co complex complex complex complex complex concentrations concentrations confirmational cor cor cor corepressor corepressor corepressor corepressor deacetylase deacetylation demonstrated development differentiation differentiation differentiation disrupts dissociate dissociation dissociation division dominant during effective encode established factors factors form forms forward from from from function fusion fusion has has hdac1 hematologic heterodimeric histone histone histone histone induce induced induces inefficient initially initiate intrinsic involved is is knowledge less leucemic leucemic leukemia leukemia leukemia leukemias leukemo lines m3 made maintained model molecular molecular myelogenous myeloid myeloid n n n negative normal novel nuclear nucleosome observation observation observation only other overcoming packed patients pharmacologic physiologic physiologic pml pml pml prior product promyelocytic protein protein protein raralpha raralpha raralpha raralpha raralpha raralpha raralpha receptor recruitment remarkable remission repressed repressed repression repression repression repressor required result resulting resulting results retinoic retinoids rxr sin3a site site specific specific src state strategies structure structure subsequent subsequent t t tails tails terminal terminal that that therapy this this tightly transcription transcription transcriptional transcriptional transcriptional transcriptional transformation transformation transformation translations treatment understanding was was was when which within

delim|delim
gfap|gfap
delim|delim
dna double-strand breaks ( dsbs ) , which can arise from normal ( e . g . v ( d ) j and meiotic recombination ) and pathological ( stalled replication forks and reactive oxygen species ) endogenous metabolic processes or from exogenous agents ( e . g . ionizing radiation and radiomimetic drugs ) , are the most severe lesions with respect to cell survival and preservation of genomic integrity . therefore , cells have evolved complex mechanisms that include cell cycle arrest , activation and increased expression of various genes including those associated with dna repair and in certain cases induction of the apoptotic pathway , to respond to dsbs . the overall cellular response to dsbs has been considered as a classical signal-transduction cascade where the lesions ( signals ) are detected by sensor proteins that activate protein kinase ( transduction ) cascades , which result in amplification and diversification of the signal through a series of downstream effector molecules ( response ) . the central dsb signaling kinases in mammalian cells are ataxia telangiectasia mutated ( atm ) and ataxia telangiectasia-related ( also known as rad3-related , atr ) , which are members of the phosphoinositide 3-kinase ( pi ( 3 ) k ) superfamily . they catalyse the phosphorylation of numerous downstream substrates that are involved in cell-cycle regulation , dna repair and apoptosis . in mammalian cells , dsbs are repaired by one of two distinct and complementary pathways – homologous recombination ( hr ) and non-homologous end-joining ( nhej ) . briefly , nhej involves processing of the broken dna terminii to make them compatible , followed by a ligation step . the core components of nhej are the ku70 / ku80 heterodimer , which binds the broken dna ends , dna-dependent protein kinase catalytic subunit ( dna-pkcs ) , a pi ( 3 ) k member that activates and forms a complex with the nuclease artemis , and the xrcc4 / dna ligase iv complex , which ligates the processed dna terminii . recently , cernunnos-xlf , a protein that is defective in a rare inherited human syndrome characterized by severe immu|3 3 3 a a a a a a a activate activates activation agents also amplification apoptosis apoptotic are are are are are are are arise arrest artemis as as associated ataxia ataxia atm atr been binds breaks briefly broken broken can cascade cascades cases catalyse catalytic cell cell cell cells cells cells cellular central cernunnos certain characterized classical compatable complementary complex complex complex components considered core cycle cycle d defective dependant detected distinct diversification dna dna dna dna dna dna dna dna dna double downstream downstream drugs dsb dsbs dsbs dsbs dsbs e e effecter end endogenous ends evolved exogenous expression followed forks forms from from g g genes genomic has have heterodimer homologous homologous hr human immu include including increased induction inherited integrity involved involves ionizing is iv j joining k k kinase kinase kinase kinases known ku70 ku80 lesions lesions ligase ligates ligation make mammalian mammalian mechanisms member members metabolic miotic molecules most mutated nhej nhej nhej non normal nuclease numerous one or overall oxygen pathological pathway pathways phosphoinositide phosphorylation pi pi pkcs preservation processed processes processing protein protein protein proteins rad3 radiation radiomimetic rare reactive recently recombination recombination regulation related related repair repair repaired replication respect respond response response result sensor series severe severe signal signal signaling signals species stalled step strand substrates subunit superfamily survival syndrome telangiectasia telangiectasia terminii terminii that that that that that them therefore they those thru transduction transduction two v various where which which which which which xlf xrcc4

infection or various exogenous antigen exposures are frequently observed ( ) , we are prompted to investigate mirna expression profile in gastric cancer cells with epigenetic treatment . interestingly , microarray analysis of ags gastric cancer cells shows that most of the mirnas , which are dramatically activated by 5-aza-cdr and pba , are located at alu repeats on chromosome 19 . alu elements are ∼280 bp in length and consist of two similar , but distinct , monomers linked by an oligo ( da ) tract . it has been reported that alu repeats in the mirna cluster on chromosome 19 can function as rna polymerase iii ( pol iii ) promoters of mirnas ( ) . here we show that chromatin remodeling at alu repeats by dna demethylation and hdac inhibition can activate expression of alu-associated mirnas , which can downregulate target oncogenes in human gas|19 19 280 5 activate activated ags alu alu alu alu alu an analysis antigen are are are are are as associated at at aza been bp but can can can cancer cancer cdr cells cells chromatin chromosome chromosome cluster consist da demethylation distinct dna downregulate dramatically elements epigenetic exogenous exposures expression expression frequently function gas gastric gastric has hdac here human iii iii infection inhibition interestingly investigate it length linked located microarray mirna mirna mirnas mirnas mirnas monomers most observed oligo oncogenes or pba pol polymerase profile promoters prompted remodeling repeats repeats repeats reported rna shew shows similar target that that that tract treatment two various we we which which

b cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia ( b-all ) is the most common form of childhood and adult all and is characterized by the clonal expansion in the bone marrow of neoplastic b cell precursors . current treatment is primarily based on combination chemotherapy . although most patients appear to be cured , survivors commonly develop morbidities that result from dose-intensified treatment with cytotoxic drugs . and , despite the use of aggressive salvage treatments , those who relapse have a dismal prognosis [ ] . the low long-term survival rate , particularly in adult patients , underscores the need for improved treatment . histone deacetylases inhibitors ( hdacis ) are emerging as a promising new class of anti-cancer agents , which have been proved to induce growth arrest , differentiation , and apoptosis in malignant cells [ , ] . in spite that many hdacis have been evaluated in clinical trials as single agents as well as in combination schemes in recent years [ ] , the pleiotropic effects and complicated molecular processes caused by structurally diverse hdacis still remain largely unknown . recently , hdacis were proved capable to inhibit proliferation and induce apoptosis in b-all cell lines [ – ] . the effects of hdacis in b-all cells as well as the underlying mechanisms , however , have not been fully elucidated . notch-1 is a member of a conserved family of closely related transmembrane receptors . members of the notch family receptors are activated upon ligand binding by a series of proteolytic cleavage events . on binding a ligand , the notch protein undergoes two proteolytic cleavages , translocates to the nucleus , where it forms a dna-binding complex with the centromere-binding factor ( cbf )-1 complex and alters transcription of target genes [ ] . the notch signaling pathway controls cell fate in multiple developmental programs and its dysregulation has been implicated in the oncogenesis of several types of cancer [ – ] . interestingly , notch signaling plays both oncogenic and tumor suppressor roles , depending on cell type [ ] . in contrast to t cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia ( all ) , where notch activation plays a key role in the leukemogenesis , induction of notch signaling in b-al|1 1 a a a a a a a a activated activation acute acute adult adult agents agents aggressive al all all all all all alters altho anti apoptosis apoptosis appear are are arrest as as as as as as b b b b b b based be been been been been binding binding binding binding bone both cancer cancer capable caused cbf cell cell cell cell cell cell cells cells centromere characterized chemotherapy childhood class cleavage cleavages clinical clonal closely combination combination common commonly complex complex complicated conserved contrast controls cured current cytotoxic deacetylases depending despite develop developmental differentiation dismal diverse dna dose drugs dysregulation effects effects elucidated emerging evaluated events expansion factor family family fate form forms from fully genes growth has have have have have hdacis hdacis hdacis hdacis hdacis histone however implicated improved induce induce induction inhibit inhibitors intensified interestingly is is is is it its key largely leukemia leukemia leukemogenesis ligand ligand lines long low lymphoblastic lymphoblastic malignant many marrow mechanisms member members molecular morbidities most most multiple need neoplastic new not notch notch notch notch notch notch notch nucleus oncogenesis oncogenic particularly pathway patients patients plays remain result role roles salvage schemes series several signaling signaling signaling single spite still structurally suppresser survival survivors t target term that that those transcription translocates transmembrane treatment treatment treatment treatments trials tumor two type types undergoes underlying underscores unknown upon use well well were where where which who years

delim|delim
cancer has long been considered a disease caused by the accumulation of genetic mutations . in the last decade , however , several global proteomic and genomic technologies have led to the realization that genetic and epigenetic events cooperate in cancer development . epigenetic alterations cause deregulation in key biological targets and pathways involved in proliferation , differentiation , tumor suppression and oncogenicity ( hatziapostolou and iliopoulos ) , thus contributing to growth and progression in a variety of cancers . epigenetic modifications in chromatin involve dna methylation , posttranslational modifications of histones and mirna modulation as well as the positioning of nucleosomes along dna . histone modifications are dependent on multi-subunit complexes that perform “ writer , ” “ eraser ” and “ reader ” functions and act in a spatially and temporarily coordinated manner ( ruthenburg et al . ; taverna et al . ) . writer and eraser functions are carried out by subunits harboring catalytic activity that add or remove marks on histones , while the reader function often requires domains that specifically recognize and bind to these marks ( ruthenburg et al . ) . chromatin structure and chromatin accessibility for transcription factors and associated proteins are mediated by chromatin-regulating complexes , which act in a stepwise and / or combinatorial manner and engage in extensive cross talk . unlike static somatic mutations affecting dna , epigenetic aberrations are potentially reversible ( as are , for example , histone marks ) and / or can be restored through epigenetic therapy targeting overexpressed or mutated epi-targets ( conte and altucci ) . different drugs directed at epigenetic-modifying enzymes have been developed to block or reverse aberrant epigenetic modifications . these include histone acetyltransferases ( hats ) , dna methyltransferases ( dnmts ) , histone deacetylases ( hdacs ) , histone methyltransferases ( hmts ) and histone demethylases ( hdms ) . to date , some of these drugs ( e . g . , azacitidine , decitabine , vorinostat and romidepsin ) have been approved by the us food and drug administration ( fda ) for the treatment of various types of cancer and precancer|a a a a aberrant aberrations accessibility accumulation acetyltransferases act act activity add administration affecting al al al along alterations altucci approved are are are are are as as as associated at azacitidine be been been been bind biological bloc can cancer cancer cancer cancers carried catalytic cause caused chromatin chromatin chromatin chromatin combinatorial complexes complexes considered conte contributing cooperate coordinated cross date deacetylases decade decitabine demethylases dependant deregulation developed development different differentiation directed disease dna dna dna dna dnmts domains drug drugs drugs e engage enzymes epi epigenetic epigenetic epigenetic epigenetic epigenetic epigenetic epigenetic eraser eraser et et et events example extensive factors fda food function functions functions g genetic genetic genomic global growth harboring has hats hatziapostolou have have have hdacs hdms histone histone histone histone histone histone histones histones hmts however iliopoulos include involve involved key last led long manner manner marks marks marks mediated methylation methyltransferases methyltransferases mirna modifications modifications modifications modifications modifying modulation multi mutated mutations mutations nucleosomes often oncogenicity or or or or or out overexpressed pathways perform positioning posttranslational potentially precancer progression proliferation proteins proteomic reader reader realisation recognise regulating remove requires restored reversable reverse romidepsin ruthenburg ruthenburg several somatic some spacially specifically static stepwise structure subunit subunits suppression talk targeting targets targets taverna technologies temporarily that that that that therapy these these these thru thus transcription treatment tumor types unlike us variety various vorinostat well which while writer writer

pr|pr
delim|delim
high mobility group box 1 ( hmgb1 ) is a 25-kda dna-binding protein that is overexpressed in various cancers . its expression is often associated with poor prognosis , higher tumor grade and metastasis . in a colon cancer study , hmgb1 was shown to be overexpressed in tumor tissue compared with adjacent normal tissue in 90 % of patients . in addition , a causative role for hmgb1 in promoting colon carcinogenesis was shown experimentally . similar results have been reported for hepatocellular carcinoma , nasopharyngeal carcinoma , prostate cancer , melanoma and breast cancer . the high prevalence of hmgb1 upregulation in diverse tumor types suggests a critical role in carcinogenesis ; however , despite a strong correlation between hmgb1 expression and negative clinical outcome , the mechanism by which hmgb1 promotes tumor growth and metastasis remains unclear . hmgb1 binds to dna without sequence specificity and aids in distorting the dna structure to allow access for repair and transcription proteins . hmgb1-deficient mice die within 24 h after birth from hypoglycemia as a result of defective glucocorticoid-mediated transcription . hmgb1 interacts with various transcription factors , including nfκb members , p53 and the tata-binding protein . interactions with these factors can promote or repress transcription depending on the cellular context . in addition to its roles in the nucleus , hmgb1 can also act as a ligand when released from dying or stressed cells . hmgb1 binds to the receptor for advanced glycation end products ( rage ) or toll-like receptors ( tlr ) 2 / 4 , which are expressed on many types of immune and tumor cells . hmgb1 binding to rage results in activation of the ras map kinase pathway and increased levels of phosphorylated p42 / 44 ( erk1 / 2 ) . the pro-tumor effects of hmgb1 are often attributed to its extracellular role , through stimulation of the mapk pathway via rage binding . functionally , preventing extracellular release of hmgb1 by drug treatment or blocking hmgb1 signaling with antibodies can reduce tumor growth and metastasis in some experimental models of cancer . in addition , rage-deficient mice are resistant to tumor formation in chemical carcinogen-induced skin cancer|1 2 2 24 25 4 44 90 a a a a a a a access act activation addition addition addition adjacent advanced after aids allow also antibodies are are are as as associated attributed be been between binding binding binding binding binds binds birth blocking box breast can can can cancer cancer cancer cancer cancer cancers carcinogen carcinogenesis carcinogenesis carcinoma carcinoma causative cells cells cellular chemical clinical colon colon compared context corelation critical defective deficient deficient depending despite die distorting diverse dna dna dna drug dying effects end erk1 experimental experimentally expressed expression expression extracellular extracellular factors factors formation from from functionally glucocorticoid glycation grade group growth growth h have hepatocellular high high higher hmgb1 hmgb1 hmgb1 hmgb1 hmgb1 hmgb1 hmgb1 hmgb1 hmgb1 hmgb1 hmgb1 hmgb1 hmgb1 hmgb1 hmgb1 however hypoglycemia immune including increased induced interactions interacts is is is its its its kda kinase levels ligand like many map mapk mechanism mediated melanoma members metastasis metastasis metastasis mice mice mobility models nasopharyngeal negative nfkappab normal nucleus often often or or or or outcome overexpressed overexpressed p42 p53 pathway pathway patients phosphorylated poor prevalence preventing pro products prognosis promote promotes promoting prostate protein protein proteins rage rage rage rage ras receptor receptors reduce release released remains repair reported repress resistant result results results role role role roles sequence shown shown signaling similar skin some specificity stimulation stressed strong structure study suggests tata that these thru tissue tissue tlr toll transcription transcription transcription transcription treatment tumor tumor tumor tumor tumor tumor tumor tumor types types unclear upregulation various various via was was when which which within without

γ h2ax|gamma h2ax
delim|delim
ino80|ino80
delim|delim
transcription of individual genes can be altered in cancer by genetic but also epigenetic lesions . focal promoter dna methylation can , for example , modify gene expression . however , studying the regulation of genes in isolation without taking into account their genomic context limits the understanding of regulatory networks in cancer . many clusters of co-regulated genes have been reported in mammalian genomes , such as the hox clusters or the classical major histocompatibility complex . the regulation of these genomic regions is complex and can result from the interaction of multiple factors including epigenetic modifications , chromatin conformation and nuclear localization , non coding rnas or polycomb complexes . prc2 and prc1 polycomb complexes take part in the delineation and regulation of gene clusters , such as the hox or kcnoqt1 clusters , notably through the deposition of h3k27me3 and chromatin compaction mechanisms . several studies have addressed the existence of co-regulated gene clusters specific to cancer cells . regions of expression bias , where genes are coordinately deregulated in tumors compared with normal tissue , have been reported in various tumor types using large-scale expression data sets . many of these regions were attributable to known dna copy-number alterations , however , a significant portion of them are independent of such genetic alterations . moreover , it has been reported that epigenetic alterations , such as histone modifications with or without aberrant dna methylation , can affect several neighboring genes in cancer and correspond to the formation of clusters of corepressed genes . recently , we and others showed that regional epigenetic silencing is frequent in bladder and prostate cancer . however , little is known about the mechanisms underlying this novel epigenetic alteration . we previously reported in bladder cancer that regional epigenetic silencing occurs in a particularly aggressive group of tumors , the tumors of the carcinoma|a a aberrant about account addressed affect aggressive also alteration alterations alterations alterations altered are are as as as attributable be been been been bias bladder bladder but can can can can cancer cancer cancer cancer cancer cancer carcinoma cells chromatin chromatin classical clusters clusters clusters clusters clusters clusters co co coding compaction compared complex complex complexes complexes conformation context coordinately copy corepressed correspond data delineation deposition deregulated dna dna dna epigenetic epigenetic epigenetic epigenetic epigenetic epigenetic example existence expression expression expression factors focal formation frequent from gene gene gene genes genes genes genes genes genes genetic genetic genomes genomic genomic group h3k27me3 has have have have histocompatability histone however however however hox hox including independent individual interaction into is is is isolation it kcnoqt1 known known large lesions limits little localisation major mammalian many many mechanisms mechanisms methylation methylation modifications modifications modify moreover multiple neighboring networks non normal notably novel nuclear number occurs or or or or others part particularly polycomb polycomb portion prc1 prc2 previously promoter prostate recently regional regional regions regions regions regulated regulated regulation regulation regulation regulatory reported reported reported reported result rnas scale sets several several showed significant silencing silencing specific studies studying such such such such take taking that that that their them these these this thru tissue transcription tumor tumors tumors tumors types underlying understanding using various we we were where without without

delim|delim
p53|p53
delim|delim
in a severe stressful situation , the levels of circulating glucocorticoids rise . if such a stressful situation occurs during pregnancy , glucocorticoids pass through the placenta and affect fetus normal development . during prenatal stress ( ps ) , glucocorticoids reach the brain and modify gene expression triggering cellular , physiological , and behavioral changes ( van den hove et al . ; baier et al . ) . in particular , hippocampal neurons from offspring of stressed mothers are negatively affected by ps ( mychasiuk et al . ) showing reduced neurogenesis ( lemaire et al . ) , decreased dendritic tree size ( hosseini-sharifabad and hadinedoushan ) , and diminished synaptic density ( hayashi et al . ) . in addition , there is a change in the expression of many genes linked to neuronal plasticity such as neurotrophic factors , neurotransmitter receptors , and synaptic proteins ( fumagalli et al . , ; van den hove et al . ; revest et al . ; baier et al . ; pallarés et al . ; monteleone et al . ; adrover et al . ) . retrospective studies on children born from stressed mothers show as attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder ( adhd ) and sleep disturbance during infancy ( beydoun and saftlas ) . for that reason , ps represents one of the main risk factors for affective disorders ( van den bergh et al . ; glover ; baier et al . ) . in response to environmental stimuli , stress-induced genetic and epigenetic changes steer neuronal remodeling , a type of neuronal plasticity . plasticity involves changes in gene expression and in the neuron ’ s structure , function , and organization that underlie many key brain processes . the stress-induced structural alterations result in functional disconnections that may underlie the neuropsychiatric disease pathophysiology but might also include clues for treatment . neural connectivity is modulated by plasticity-related genes whose expression is controlled by different transcription factors . among them , the serum response factor ( srf ) and the yin yang 1 ( yy1 ) factor have been related to chronic stress . srf promotes resilience to chronic social stress ( vialou et al . ) and yy1 participates in anxiety|1 a a a a addition adhd adrover affect affected affective al al al al al al al al al al al al al al al also alterations among anxiety are as as attention baier baier baier been behavioral bergh beydoun born brain brain but cellular change changes changes changes children chronic chronic circulating clues connectivity controlled decreased deficit den den den dendritic density development different diminished disconnections disease disorder disorders disturbance during during during environmental epigenetic et et et et et et et et et et et et et et et expression expression expression expression cenp-a cenp-a|a a cenp cenp
delim|delim
the chromatin remodeler swi / snf harbors a large number of subunits ( 12 genes in yeast , 29 in human ; see [ ] for review ; fig . a ) , whose functions are conserved among eukaryotes [ ] . early work identified swi / snf as a transcription activator through histones sliding and alteration of the nucleosome structure [ ] . since then , it has been implicated in dna replication , damage repair , apoptosis , metabolism , and cell differentiation . mutations or aberrant expression of swi / snf subunits are frequently found in a broad range of cancer subtypes [ ] , hinting at subtle and tissue-specific regulation of the swi / snf subunits . contribution of individual swi / snf subunits to the complex function and its structure stability have been extensively studied in yeast [ , ] and humans [ ] . these studies have provided insights into how mutations in individual subunits or their epigenetic silencing affect gene expression and favor carcinogenesis [ – ] . the catalytic subunits , brg1 or brm , are essential for enzymatic function and the structural integrity of swi / snf , and have been intensely studied . in contrast , tissue-specific subunits ( brg1 associated factors , or baf ) and non-catalytic subunits of swi / snf , e . g . , smarcd3 , one of three paralogs of smarcd ( , or baf60a / b / c , respectively ) , remain poorly characterized . smarcd1 / 2 / 3 are mutually exclusive , tissue-specific , and their function is only partially redundant as they cannot complement each other [ , ] . they have been identified as recruiter of the swi / snf complex to target site on the chromatin through interaction with protein partners [ , ] . smarcd1 / 2 role in the complex have been better characterized ad smarcd3 precise function remains to be discovered . however , previous work smarcd3 shed light on smarcd3 as a potentially essential subunit . for instance , smarcd3 is critical for cell differentiation via direct interactions with partners such as myod , thus coordinating cell differentiation cascades through transcriptional activation of genes , and through epigenetic reprogramming [ , ] . recent studies have associated smarcd3 levels and breast|12 2 2 29 3 a a a a a aberrant activation activator ad affect alteration among apoptosis are are are are as as as as as associated associated at b baf baf60a be been been been been been better breast brg1 brg1 brm broad c cancer cannot carcinogenesis cascades catalytic catalytic cell cell cell characterized characterized chromatin chromatin complement complex complex complex conserved contrast contribution coordinating critical damage differentiation differentiation differentiation direct discovered dna e each early enzymatic epigenetic epigenetic essential essential eukaryotes exclusive expression expression extensively factors favor fig found frequently function function function function functions g gene genes genes harbors has have have have have have have hinting histones how however human humans identified identified implicated individual individual insights instance integrity intensely interaction interactions into is is it its large levels light metabolism mutations mutations mutually myod non nucleosome number one only or or or or or other paralogs partially partners partners poorly potentially precise previous protein provided range recent recruiter redundant regulation remain remains remodeler repair replication reprogramming respectively review role see shed silencing since site sliding smarcd smarcd1 smarcd1 smarcd3 smarcd3 smarcd3 smarcd3 smarcd3 smarcd3 snf snf snf snf snf snf snf snf specific specific specific stability structural structure structure studied studied studies studies subtle subtypes subunit subunits subunits subunits subunits subunits subunits subunits subunits such swi swi swi swi swi swi swi swi target their their then these they they three thru thru thru thru thus tissue tissue tissue transcription transcriptional via whose work work yeast yeast

delim|delim
gut microbiota is designated as “ the fellow travelers , ” as they are the permanent residents of our gastrointestinal tract ( git ) . the gut microbiome constitutes a variety of different microorganisms , which include several species of viruses , bacteria , protozoa , and fungi . this microbiome shows vast diversity amongst different population groups and has a significant influence on human health , disease state , and overall well-being ( zmora et al . ) . the number of gut microbes within the git is estimated to be approximately 100 trillion , which is 10 times the number of cells found in the human body . the gut microbiome is about 150 times greater than that of the human genome and encodes 100-fold more unique genes than our genome , which suggests their vast possibilities in influencing human health . extensive research in the recent past has suggested a direct association of gut microbiota with a variety of disorders including diabetes mellitus , atherosclerosis , hypertension , heart disorders , cardiovascular complications , and cns disorders such as alzheimer ’ s disease ( ad ) or parkinsonism . the gut microbiota has been found to modulate the pathogenesis of several neurodegenerative disorders ; however , the exact mechanism involved is yet to be discovered ( bonfili et al . ) . ad is one of the most prevalent irreversible neurodegenerative disorders resulting in progressive dementia . ad patients show short-term memory loss , neuronal hypotrophy , impaired coordination capabilities , aggregation of amyloid-β ( aβ ) peptides , accumulation of extracellular amyloidal plaques and neurofibrillary tangles , synaptic dysfunction , impaired synaptic plasticity , neurodegeneration , and neuroinflammation ( mir et al . ; skaper et al . ) . accumulated evidence suggests that dysbiosis leads to the destruction of the intestinal barrier and results in increased intestinal permeability . this leads to increased systemic concentration of inflammatory mediators such as cytokines and bacterial metabolites , which in turn may impair the integrity of the blood – brain barrier ( bbb ) and promote neuroinflammation and neurodegeneration , thereby contributing to the development and progression of cns disorders such as ad|10 100 100 150 a a a a abeta about accumulated accumulation ad ad ad ad aggregation al al al al alzheimer amongst amyloid amyloidal approximately are as as as as as association atherosclerosis bacteria bacterial barrier barrier bbb be be been being beta blood body bonfili brain capabilities cardiovascular cells cns cns complications concentration constitutes contributing coordination cytokines dementia designated destruction development diabetes different different direct discovered disease disease disfunction disorders disorders disorders disorders disorders disorders diversity dysbiosis encodes estimated et et et et evidence exact extensive extracellular fellow fold found found fungi gastrointestinal genes genome genome git git greater groups gut gut gut gut gut gut has has has health health heart however human human human human hypertension hypotrophy impair impaired impaired include including increased increased inflammatory influence influencing integrity intestinal intestinal involved irreversible is is is is is is leads leads loss may mechanism mediators mellitus memory metabolites microbes microbiome microbiome microbiome microbiota microbiota microbiota microorganisms mir modulate more most neurodegeneration neurodegeneration neurodegenerative neurodegenerative neurofibrillary neuroinflammation neuroinflammation neuronal number number one or our our overall parkinsonism past pathogenesis patients peptides permanent permeability plaques plasticity population possibilities prevalent progression progressive promote protozoa recent research residents resulting results s several several shew short shows significant skaper species state such such such suggested suggests suggests synaptic synaptic systemic tangles term than than that that their thereby they this this times times tract travelers trillion turn unique variety variety vast vast viruses well which which which which within yet zmora
